claim: If you put on one ring, a ring will be on your finger.

supporting.text: Placing a ring on a finger physically positions the ring around the finger.

attacks.text: Placing a ring on a finger physically positions the ring around the finger.
If the finger is missing or amputated, placing a ring on it does not result in a ring being on the finger.
Even with an amputated finger, the ring can be placed on a prosthetic or symbolic representation of the finger, maintaining the claim's validity in a broader sense.
If the ring is too large, it may slip off the finger immediately, failing to stay on the finger.
Properly sized rings are designed to stay on the finger, making slippage an exception rather than the norm.

supporting.text: A ring is designed to encircle a finger when worn.

attacks.text: A ring is designed to encircle a finger when worn.
Some rings are not designed for fingers (e.g., toe rings, nose rings).
The claim specifies 'one ring' and 'your finger,' implying a typical finger ring.
A ring might be too large or small to stay on the finger when worn.
Standard ring sizing ensures most rings fit fingers properly when worn.

supporting.text: The act of putting on a ring involves sliding it onto a finger.

attacks.text: The act of putting on a ring involves sliding it onto a finger.
Some rings are designed to be worn on body parts other than fingers, such as toes or ears.
The term 'ring' commonly implies finger-worn jewelry unless specified otherwise, making non-finger usage rare and context-dependent.
If a person has no fingers, putting on a ring cannot result in a ring being on their finger.
The claim implicitly assumes the presence of fingers, as it is the default anatomical context for ring-wearing.

supporting.text: A ring cannot be on a finger unless it is placed there.

attacks.text: A ring cannot be on a finger unless it is placed there.
A ring could be on a finger if it was already there before the action of putting it on.
The claim specifies 'put on one ring,' implying the ring was not already on the finger prior to the action.
A ring could be placed on a finger by someone else, not necessarily by the person performing the action.
The claim does not specify agency, but the common interpretation is that the person putting on the ring is the one whose finger it ends up on.
